message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: PROPOSITIONAL REASONING
Paper Abstract: Propositional (Boolean) logic is conceptually simple. It provides a rich basis for the representation of finite structures, but is computationally complex. Many current verification techniques are based on propositional encodings.Propositional representations lead to problems that are, in general, computationally intractable. Nevertheless, datastructures for representing propositional formulae, and algorithms for reasoning about them, provide generic tools that can be applied to a wide variety of computational problems. Natural problem instances are often effectively solved by these generic approaches.There is a growing literature of algorithms for propositional reasoning, and of techniques for propositional representation of tasks in areas ranging from cryptography, constraint satisfaction and planning, to system design, validation and verification.We present a model-theoretic account of propositional encodings for questions of logical validity. Validity is characterised model-thoretically. For restricted logics, checking validity in a restricted class of models may suffce. Classes of structures on a finite domain can be encoded as propositional theories, and validity in such a class is encoded propositionally, by means of a syntactic translation to a propositional formula.This provides a unified setting for generating efficient propositional encodings suitable for analysis using BDD or SAT packages.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Search Results for "Propositional Logic"

Here's an overview of what I found about propositional logic:

### Definition and Overview

Propositional logic is a branch of logic, also called statement logic, sentential calculus, propositional calculus, sentential logic, or sometimes zeroth-order logic.(no content)It deals with propositions (which can be true or false) and relations between propositions, including the construction of arguments based on them.

### Key Components

Propositional logic is typically studied with a formal language, in which propositions are represented by letters, which are called propositional variables.(no content)Compound propositions are formed by connecting propositions by logical connectives representing the truth functions of conjunction, disjunction, implication, biconditional, and negation.(no content)In English, these connectives are expressed by the words "and" (conjunction), "or" (disjunction), "not" (negation), "if" (material conditional), and "if and only if" (biconditional).

### Core Principles

The most thoroughly researched branch of propositional logic is classical truth-functional propositional logic, in which formulas are interpreted as having precisely one of two possible truth values, the truth value of true or the truth value of false.

### Distinction from Other Logics

Unlike first-order logic, propositional logic does not deal with non-logical objects, predicates about them, or quantifiers. However, propositional logic is the foundation of first-order logic and higher-order logic.

Web search results for query: "SAT Solver"

Links: [{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"GRASP (SAT solver) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GRASP_(SAT_solver)"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Satz (SAT solver) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satz_(SAT_solver)"},{"title":"Category:SAT solvers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:SAT_solvers"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"DPLL(T) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL(T)"},{"title":"Davis–Putnam algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis-Putnam_algorithm"},{"title":"DPLL algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL_algorithm"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of SAT Solvers based on the search results:

## What is a SAT Solver?

A SAT solver is a computer program that solves the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT). On input a formula over Boolean variables, such as "(x or y) and (x or not y)", a SAT solver outputs whether the formula is satisfiable (meaning there are possible values that make the formula true) or unsatisfiable (meaning there are no such values).

## Key Algorithms and Approaches

SAT solvers are usually developed using one of two core approaches: the Davis–Putnam–Logemann–Loveland algorithm (DPLL) and conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL). A DPLL SAT solver employs a systematic backtracking searchprocedure to explore the (exponentially sized) space of variable assignments looking for satisfying assignments.(no content)Conflict-driven solvers, such as conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL), augment the basic DPLL search algorithm with efficient conflict analysis, clause learning, backjumping, a "two-watched-literals" form of unit propagation, adaptive branching, and random restarts.(no content)Most state-of-the-art SAT solvers are based on the CDCL framework as of 2019.

## Computational Complexity

By a result known as the Cook–Levin theorem, Boolean satisfiability is an NP-complete problem in general. As a result, only algorithms with exponential worst-case complexity are known.

## Applications and Impact

Modern SAT solvers have had a significant impact on fields including software verification, program analysis, constraint solving, artificial intelligence, electronic design automation, and operations research.

## Notable SAT Solvers

Google's CP-SAT solver, part of OR-Tools, won gold medals at the Minizinc constraint programming competitions in editions 2018 up until 2025.

Web search results for query: "Formal Verification"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Verification condition generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_condition_generator"},{"title":"High-level verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Murφ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mur%CF%86"},{"title":"Joseph Sifakis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Sifakis"},{"title":"IBM Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Haifa_Labs"}]

## Formal Verification

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

### Key Approaches

There are several main techniques used in formal verification:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model, which usually consists of exploring all states and transitions in the model, by using smart and domain-specific abstraction techniques to consider whole groups of states in a single operation and reduce computing time.

2. **Deductive Verification**: This consists of generating from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants or automatic theorem provers, including satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

3. **Other Subareas**: Formal verification includes deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.

### Current Usage

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Industrial use is limited owing to the computational cost of existing techniques.

### Applications

Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.

## Formal Verification

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

### Key Approaches

There are several main techniques used in formal verification:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model, which usually consists of exploring all states and transitions in the model, by using smart and domain-specific abstraction techniques to consider whole groups of states in a single operation and reduce computing time.

2. **Deductive Verification**: This consists of generating from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants or automatic theorem provers, including satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

3. **Other Subareas**: Formal verification includes deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.

### Current Usage

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Industrial use is limited owing to the computational cost of existing techniques.

### Applications

Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.

## Cryptography - Search Results

I've performed a web search on cryptography. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Cryptography, or cryptology, is the practice and study of techniques for secure communication in the presence of adversarial behavior.(no content)More generally, cryptography is about constructing and analyzing protocols that prevent third parties or the public from reading private messages.

### Core Concepts

Cryptography prior to the modern age was effectively synonymous with encryption, converting readable information (plaintext) to unintelligible nonsense text (ciphertext), which can only be read by reversing the process (decryption).(no content)Core concepts related to information security (data confidentiality, data integrity, authentication and non-repudiation) are also central to cryptography.

### Types of Cryptosystems

There are two main types of cryptosystems: symmetric and asymmetric. In symmetric systems, the only ones known until the 1970s, the same secret key encrypts and decrypts a message.(no content)Asymmetric systems use a "public key" to encrypt a message and a related "private key" to decrypt it. The advantage of asymmetric systems is that the public key can be freely published, allowing parties to establish secure communication without having a shared secret key.

### Common Algorithms

Secure symmetric algorithms include the commonly used AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) which replaced the older DES (Data Encryption Standard).(no content)Examples of asymmetric systems include Diffie–Hellman key exchange, RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman), ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography), and Post-quantum cryptography.

### Practical Applications

Practical applications of cryptography include electronic commerce, chip-based payment cards, digital currencies, computer passwords and military communications.

## Search Results for "Planning Artificial Intelligence"

I found comprehensive information about AI planning. Here's what the search revealed:

### What is AI Planning?

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

### Key Concepts

Planners typically input a domain model (a description of a set of possible actions which model the domain) as well as the specific problem to be solved specified by the initial state and goal. Such planners are called "domain independent" to emphasize the fact that they can solve planning problems from a wide range of domains.

### Approach Mechanisms

Artificial action selection mechanisms can be divided into several categories: symbol-based systems sometimes known as classical planning, distributed solutions, and reactive or dynamic planning.

### Planning Languages and Standards

The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence (AI) planning languages. It was first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the 1998/2000 International Planning Competition (IPC) possible.(no content)PDDL is a human-readable format for problems in automated planning that gives a description of the possible states of the world, a description of the set of possible actions, a specific initial state of the world, and a specific set of desired goals.

### Key Algorithm

Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995. Graphplan takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces, if one is possible, a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

## Binary Decision Diagram

Here are the key findings about Binary Decision Diagrams from the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

A binary decision diagram (BDD) is a data structure used to represent a Boolean function.(no content)BDDs can be considered as a compressed representation of sets or relations.

### How They Work

The value of a boolean function can be determined by following a path in its BDD down to a terminal, making a binary decision at each node where a solid line is followed if the value of the variable at the node is true and a dotted line if it is false.

### Key Variants

BDDs that are ordered and reduced can be called Reduced Ordered Binary Decision Diagrams (ROBDD). Additionally, researchers have suggested refinements on the BDD data structure giving way to a number of related graphs, such as BMD (binary moment diagrams), ZDD (zero-suppressed decision diagrams), FBDD (free binary decision diagrams), FDD (functional decision diagrams), PDD (parity decision diagrams), and MTBDDs (multiple terminal BDDs).

### Applications

BDDs are extensively used in CAD software to synthesize circuits (logic synthesis) and in formal verification.(no content)There are several lesser known applications of BDD, including fault tree analysis, Bayesian reasoning, product configuration, and private information retrieval.

### Historical Significance

"One of the only really fundamental data structures that came out in the last twenty-five years" is how Donald Knuth describes BDDs, noting that Bryant's 1986 paper was for some time one of the most-cited papers in computer science.

Web search results for query: "Boolean Logic"

Links: [{"title":"Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Boolean expression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_expression"},{"title":"Boolean function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_function"},{"title":"George Boole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Boole"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"},{"title":"Boolean operation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_operation"},{"title":"Boolean-valued function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean-valued_function"},{"title":"Logic alphabet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_alphabet"},{"title":"Boolean-valued model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean-valued_model"}]

Here are the search results for "Boolean Logic":

## Overview

Boolean algebra is a branch of algebra in mathematics where the values of variables are the truth values true and false, usually denoted by 1 and 0. Boolean logic is sometimes used to denote propositional calculus performed in this way.

## Key Concepts

A Boolean expression (also known as logical expression) is an expression used in programming languages that produces a Boolean value when evaluated—either true or false. A Boolean function is a function whose arguments and result assume values from a two-element set (usually {true, false}, {0,1} or {−1,1}).

## Basic Operations

Most programming languages have the Boolean operators OR, AND and NOT. Exclusive or (XOR) is used to distinguish it from disjunction as the inclusive kind, and it excludes the possibility of both x and y being true.

## History and Applications

George Boole is best known as the author of The Laws of Thought (1854), which contains Boolean algebra. Boolean logic, essential to computer programming, is credited with helping to lay the foundations for the Information Age.

Boolean functions play a basic role in questions of complexity theory as well as the design of processors for digital computers, where they are implemented in electronic circuits using logic gates.

Web search results for query: "Constraint Satisfaction Problem"

Links: [{"title":"Constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_problem"},{"title":"Weighted constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_constraint_satisfaction_problem"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction dual problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_dual_problem"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction"},{"title":"Complexity of constraint satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complexity_of_constraint_satisfaction"},{"title":"Local search (constraint satisfaction) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_search_(constraint_satisfaction)"},{"title":"Constraint graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_graph"},{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Hierarchical constraint satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_constraint_satisfaction"},{"title":"Min-conflicts algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Min_conflicts_algorithm"}]

## Overview of Constraint Satisfaction Problems

Constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs) are mathematical questions defined as a set of objects whose state must satisfy a number of constraints or limitations.(no content)CSPs represent the entities in a problem as a homogeneous collection of finite constraints over variables, which is solved by constraint satisfaction methods.

## Research and Applications

CSPs are the subject of research in both artificial intelligence and operations research, since the regularity in their formulation provides a common basis to analyze and solve problems of many seemingly unrelated families.(no content)Constraint programming (CP) is the field of research that specifically focuses on tackling these kinds of problems.

## Examples

Examples of problems that can be modeled as a constraint satisfaction problem include: Sudoku, crosswords, futoshiki, Kakuro (Cross Sums), Numbrix/Hidato, Zebra Puzzle, and many other logic puzzles. Additionally, "Real life" examples include automated planning, lexical disambiguation, musicology, product configuration and resource allocation.

## Complexity and Solution Methods

CSPs often exhibit high complexity, requiring a combination of heuristics and combinatorial search methods to be solved in a reasonable time.(no content)Solving a constraint satisfaction problem on a finite domain is an NP-complete problem in general.(no content)The most-used techniques are variants of backtracking, constraint propagation, and local search.(no content)Constraint propagation techniques are methods used to modify a constraint satisfaction problem. More precisely, they are methods that enforce a form of local consistency, which are conditions related to the consistency of a group of variables and/or constraints.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of model theory, semantics, and logic:

## Key Concepts

Model theory is the study of the relationship between formal theories (a collection of sentences in a formal language expressing statements about a mathematical structure), and their models (those structures in which the statements of the theory hold).(no content)In logic, the semantics of logic or formal semantics is the study of the meaning and interpretation of formal languages, formal systems, and (idealizations of) natural languages.(no content)Proof theory is syntactic in nature, in contrast to model theory, which is semantic in nature.

## Major Approaches to Semantics

The development of formal semantics has led to several influential approaches, including model-theoretic semantics (pioneered by Alfred Tarski), proof-theoretic semantics (associated with Gerhard Gentzen and Michael Dummett), possible worlds semantics (developed by Saul Kripke and others for modal logic and related systems), algebraic semantics (connecting logic to abstract algebra), and game semantics (interpreting logical validity through game-theoretic concepts).

## Model-Theoretic Semantics

The archetype of model-theoretic semantics is Alfred Tarski's semantic theory of truth, based on his T-schema, and is one of the founding concepts of model theory. This is the most widespread approach, and is based on the idea that the meaning of the various parts of the propositions are given by the possible ways we can give a recursively specified group of interpretation functions from them to some predefined mathematical domains.

Based on the web search results, here's information about logical validity and model theory:

## Logical Validity

In logic, specifically in deductive reasoning, an argument is valid if and only if it takes a form that makes it impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion nevertheless to be false.(no content)It is not required for a valid argument to have premises that are actually true, but to have premises that, if they were true, would guarantee the truth of the argument's conclusion.(no content)The validity of an argument can be tested, proved or disproved, and depends on its logical form.

## Model Theory

In mathematical logic, model theory is the study of the relationship between formal theories (a collection of sentences in a formal language expressing statements about a mathematical structure), and their models (those structures in which the statements of the theory hold).(no content)The aspects investigated include the number and size of models of a theory, the relationship of different models to each other, and their interaction with the formal language itself.

## Validity in Model Theory

A theory is satisfiable if at least one interpretation makes every formula in the theory true, and valid if every formula is true in every interpretation. This semantic approach to validity is central to how model theory understands logical validity—a formula or theory is valid when it holds across all possible models that satisfy the formal language.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks are now complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the "Propositional Reasoning" paper and extracted all key technologies and methodologies:

### Paper Classification
- **Type:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel model-theoretic account of propositional encodings)

### Identified Triples (10 total)

**Concepts Used:**
- [Propositional logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_logic)
- [Boolean algebra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra)

**Tools Used:**
- [SAT solver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver)
- [Binary decision diagram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_decision_diagram)

**Tasks/Applications Using Propositional Reasoning:**
- [Constraint satisfaction problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_problem)
- [Automated planning and scheduling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling)
- [Cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography)
- [Formal verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)

**Novel Contributions Proposed:**
- [Model theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_theory) - the paper's model-theoretic characterization approach
- [Validity (logic)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validity_(logic)) - the unified setting for encoding validity checking

The analysis validates successfully with all 10 triples properly structured with correct Wikipedia URLs, entity types, relations, and relevance descriptions.
